contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox music genre |name = Ghettotech |color = black |bgcolor = silver |stylistic_origins = [[Ghetto house]], [[Electro (music)|electro]], [[Glitch (music)|glitch]], [[Hip hop music|hip hop]], [[techno]], [[Miami bass]], [[drum and bass]] |cultural_origins = Late 1990s,<br />{{nowrap|[[Detroit, Michigan|Detroit]]}} |instruments = [[Music sequencer|Sequencer]], [[turntablism|turntables]], [[sampler (musical instrument)|sampler]], [[drum machine]], [[synthesiser]], [[keyboard instrument|keyboard]], [[personal computer]] |popularity = |fusiongenres = |subgenrelist = |regional_scenes = [[Detroit, Michigan|Detroit]] |local_scenes = |other_topics = [[Ghetto house]] }} [[Image:GhettoTech DJs.JPG|thumb|300px|A heavy hitter of the genre, [[DJ Assault]] (to the right) with a big player in Chicago's related [[Ghetto House]] scene, [[DJ Funk]], (to the left).]] '''Ghettotech''' or Detroit club music is a form of [[electronic dance music |electronic music]] originating from [[Detroit, Michigan|Detroit]]. It combines elements of Chicago's [[ghetto house]] with [[electro (music)|electro]], [[glitch (music)|glitch]], [[hip hop music|hip hop]] and [[Techno music|techno]]. It is usually faster than most other dance music genres, at roughly 145 to 170 bpm, and sometimes features [[pornographic]] lyrics. As [[DJ Godfather]] puts it, "the beats are really gritty, really raw, nothing polished."<ref>XLR8R TV Episode 13: Detroit Ghettotech. 14 Aug. 2007. <http://youtube.com/watch?v=NGFpF6vCV18&feature=related>.</ref> Ghettotech was born as a DJing style, inspired by the eclecticism of [[The Electrifying Mojo]] and the fast-paced mixing and turntablism of [[Jeff Mills|The Wizard]], with DJs mixing genres including [[Miami bass]], [[ghetto house]], [[Electro music|electro]], [[Glitch music|glitch]], [[hip hop]] and [[Detroit techno]]. The general BPM of the music's mixing style increased over time. Moving into 2011, ghettotech is finding a strong resurgence, [[tech house]] being an influence. Ghettotech is an integral part of the [[Detroit Electronic Music Festival]], an annual event. A Detroit ghettotech style of dancing is called the jit. It is an improvisational dance that mainly centers around the fast movement of the feet. Chicago's equivalent dance style is Juke, where the focus is on the footwork dating back to the late 1980s.<ref>XLR8R TV Episode 13: Detroit Ghettotech. 14 Aug. 2007. <http://youtube.com/watch?v=NGFpF6vCV18&feature=related>.</ref> ==References== {{reflist}} ==Other Articles== {{Portal|Metro Detroit|Music|Hip hop}} * [http://www.stylusmagazine.com/articles/weekly_article/ghettotech-the-bluffers-guide.htm "Ghettotech, The Bluffer's Guide"] article at Stylus Magazine. * [http://www.globaldarkness.com/articles/ghettotech1.htm "Ghettotech"] article at Global Darkness. ==External links== *[From Jack to Juke: 25 Years of Ghetto House. http://vimeo.com/36275353] * [http://www.4-player-records.com/ 4 Player Records]: Pan-European label Started in February 2004 by a DJ / Producer collective with members in Germany, Scotland, The Netherlands, Italy, and Sweden.
